L-Dopa (levodopa) is combined with carbidopa in the treatment of parkinsonism primarily to inhibit the peripheral conversion of L-Dopa to dopamine. This allows for a greater amount of L-Dopa to reach the central nervous system (CNS), thereby increasing its efficacy in alleviating parkinsonism symptoms. Carbidopa does not decrease the efficacy of L-Dopa; rather, it enhances it by reducing side effects associated with peripheral dopamine production and allowing for lower doses of L-Dopa to be used while maintaining therapeutic effectiveness.
